#A Short Introduction

= Compiling Ulib =

== Compiling Ulib on Linux OSes ==
  # Untar/svn checkout the source.
  # cd ulib_src_dir/
  # make
 
At this time, you will have all necessary headers in ulib_src_dir/include/ and libraries in ulib_src_dir/lib/.

== Compiling Ulib on Windows ==
  # We recommend you to use the pre-compiled binaries in the download section for windows. Modifications are needed in order to compile.

= Examples =
I assume you have already compiled ulib. Now let's take a look at some simple examples.

== Play with aligned hashmap ==
{{{
#include <stdio.h>
#include <ulib/alignhash.h>  // with ulib/ prefix

using namespace ulib;  // namespace needed since 1.2.1 beta

int main()
{
        align_hash_map<int,int> intmap;  // declare a int-to-int map

        intmap[1] = 2;
        intmap[2] = 3;

        printf("intmap[1] = %d\n", intmap[1]);
        printf("intmap[2] = %d\n", intmap[2]);

        return 0;
}
}}}

Save above code to intmap.cpp, and then compile it with g++ -I path_to_ulib_include intmap.cpp -o intmap. The output of the program should be:
{{{
intmap[1] = 2
intmap[2] = 3
}}}
Just as what we expected.
